div.head: Act 1, Scene 1
div.stage: A hall in the DUKE'S palace.
Enter DUKE, AEGEON, Gaoler, Officers, and other Attendants.

sp.speaker: Aegeon
sp.l: Proceed, Solinus, to procure my fall
And by the doom of death end woes and all.

sp.speaker: Solinus
sp.l: Merchant of Syracuse, plead no more;
I am not partial to infringe our laws:
The enmity and discord which of late
Sprung from the rancorous outrage of your duke
To merchants, our well-dealing countrymen,
Who wanting guilders to redeem their lives
Have sealed his rigorous statutes with their bloods,
Excludes all pity from our threatening looks.
For, since the mortal and intestine jars
'Twixt thy seditious countrymen and us,
It hath in solemn synods been decreed,
Both by the Syracusians and ourselves,
To admit no traffic to our adverse towns:
Nay, more,
If any born at Ephesus be seen
At any Syracusian marts and fairs;
Again: if any Syracusian born
Come to the bay of Ephesus, he dies,
His goods confiscate to the duke's dispose,
Unless a thousand marks be levied,
To quit the penalty and to ransom him.
Thy substance, valued at the highest rate,
Cannot amount unto a hundred marks;
Therefore by law thou art condemned to die.

sp.speaker: Aegeon
sp.l: Yet this my comfort: when your words are done,
My woes end likewise with the evening sun.

sp.speaker: Solinus
sp.l: Well, Syracusian, say in brief the cause
Why thou departed'st from thy native home
And for what cause thou camest to Ephesus,

sp.speaker: Aegeon
sp.l: A heavier task could not have been imposed
Than I to speak my griefs unspeakable:
Yet, that the world may witness that my end
Was wrought by nature, not by vile offence,
I'll utter what my sorrow gives me leave.
In Syracusa was I born, and wed
Unto a woman, happy but for me,
And by me, had not our hap been bad.
With her I lived in joy; our wealth increased
By prosperous voyages I often made
To Epidamnum; till my factor's death
And the great care of goods at random left
Drew me from kind embracements of my spouse:
From whom my absence was not six months old
Before herself, almost at fainting under
The pleasing punishment that women bear,
Had made provision for her following me
And soon and safe arrived where I was.
There had she not been long but she became
A joyful mother of two goodly sons;
And, which was strange, the one so like the other
As could not be distinguished but by names.
That very hour, and in the selfsame inn,
A mean woman was delivered
Of such a burden, male twins, both alike:
Those, â for their parents were exceeding poor, â
I bought and brought up to attend my sons.
My wife, not meanly proud of two such boys,
Made daily motions for our home return:
Unwilling I agreed; alas! too soon,
We came aboard.
A league from Epidamnum had we sailed,
Before the always-wind-obeying deep
Gave any tragic instance of our harm:
But longer did we not retain much hope;
For what obscured light the heavens did grant
Did but convey unto our fearful minds
A doubtful warrant of immediate death;
Which though myself would gladly have embraced,
Yet the incessant weepings of my wife,
Weeping before for what she saw must come,
And piteous plainings of the pretty babes,
That mourned for fashion, ignorant what to fear,
Forced me to seek delays for them and me.
And this it was, for other means was none:
The sailors sought for safety by our boat,
And left the ship, then sinking-ripe, to us:
My wife, more careful for the latter-born,
Had fastened him unto a small spare mast,
Such as seafaring men provide for storms;
To him one of the other twins was bound,
Whilst I had been like heedful of the other:
The children thus disposed, my wife and I,
Fixing our eyes on whom our care was fixed,
Fastened ourselves at either end the mast;
And floating straight, obedient to the stream,
Was carried towards Corinth, as we thought.
At length the sun, gazing upon the earth,
Dispersed those vapours that offended us;
And, by the benefit of his wished light,
The seas waxed calm, and we discovered
Two ships from far making amain to us,
Of Corinth that, of Epidaurus this:
But ere they came, â O, let me say no more!
Gather the sequel by that went before.

sp.speaker: Solinus
sp.l: Nay, forward, old man; do not break off so;
For we may pity, though not pardon thee.

sp.speaker: Aegeon
sp.l: O, had the gods done so, I had not now
Worthily termed them merciless to us!
For, ere the ships could meet by twice five leagues,
We were encountered by a mighty rock;
Which being violently borne upon,
Our helpful ship was splitted in the midst;
So that, in this unjust divorce of us,
Fortune had left to both of us alike
What to delight in, what to sorrow for.
Her part, poor soul! seeming as burdened
With lesser weight but not with lesser woe,
Was carried with more speed before the wind;
And in our sight they three were taken up
By fishermen of Corinth, as we thought.
At length, another ship had seized on us;
And, knowing whom it was their hap to save,
Gave healthful welcome to their shipwracked guests;
And would have reft the fishers of their prey,
Had not their bark been very slow of sail;
And therefore homeward did they bend their course.
Thus have you heard me severed from my bliss;
That by misfortunes was my life prolonged,
To tell sad stories of my own mishaps.

sp.speaker: Solinus
sp.l: And, for the sake of them thou sorrowest for,
Do me the favour to dilate at full
What have befallen of them and thee till now.

sp.speaker: Aegeon
sp.l: My youngest boy, and yet my eldest care,
At eighteen years became inquisitive
After his brother: and importuned me
That his attendant â so his case was like,
Reft of his brother, but retained his name â
Might bear him company in the quest of him:
Whom whilst I laboured of a love to see,
I hazarded the loss of whom I loved.
Five summers have I spent in furthest Greece,
Roaming clean through the bounds of Asia,
And, coasting homeward, came to Ephesus;
Hopeless to find, yet loath to leave unsought
Or that or any place that harbours men.
But here must end the story of my life;
And happy were I in my timely death,
Could all my travels warrant me they live.

sp.speaker: Solinus
sp.l: Hapless Aegeon, whom the fates have marked
To bear the extremity of dire mishap!
Now, trust me, were it not against our laws,
Against my crown, my oath, my dignity,
Which princes, would they, may not disannul,
My soul should sue as advocate for thee.
But, though thou art adjudged to the death
And passed sentence may not be recalled
But to our honour's great disparagement,
Yet will I favour thee in what I can.
Therefore, merchant, I'll limit thee this day
To seek thy health by beneficial help:
Try all the friends thou hast in Ephesus;
Beg thou, or borrow, to make up the sum,
And live; if no, then thou art doomed to die
Gaoler, take him to thy custody.

sp.speaker: Gaoler
sp.l: I will, my lord.

sp.speaker: Aegeon
sp.l: Hopeless and helpless doth Aegeon wend,
But to procrastinate his lifeless end. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 1, Scene 2
div.stage: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse, DROMIO of Syracuse, and First Merchant.

sp.speaker: First Merchant
sp.l: Therefore give out you are of Epidamnum,
Lest that your goods too soon be confiscate.
This very day a Syracusian merchant
Is apprehended for arrival here;
And not being able to buy out his life
According to the statute of the town,
Dies ere the weary sun set in the west.
There is your money that I had to keep.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Go bear it to the Centaur, where we host,
And stay there, Dromio, till I come to thee.
Within this hour it will be dinnertime:
Till that, I'll view the manners of the town,
Peruse the traders, gaze upon the buildings,
And then return and sleep within mine inn,
For with long travel I am stiff and weary.
Get thee away.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: Many a man would take you at your word,
And go indeed, having so good a mean. Exit.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: A trusty villain, sir, that very oft,
When I am dull with care and melancholy,
Lightens my humour with his merry jests.
What, will you walk with me about the town,
And then go to my inn and dine with me?

sp.speaker: First Merchant
sp.l: I am invited, sir, to certain merchants,
Of whom I hope to make much benefit;
I crave your pardon. Soon at five o'clock,
Please you, I'll meet with you upon the mart
And afterward consort you till bed-time:
My present business calls me from you now.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Farewell till then: I will go lose myself
And wander up and down to view the city.

sp.speaker: First Merchant
sp.l: Sir, I commend you to your own content. Exit.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: He that commends me to mine own content
Commends me to the thing I cannot get.
I to the world am like a drop of water
That in the ocean seeks another drop,
Who, falling there to find his fellow forth,
Unseen, inquisitive, confounds himself:
So I, to find a mother and a brother,
In quest of them, unhappy, ah, lose myself. Enter DROMIO of Ephesus.
Here comes the almanac of my true date.
What now? how chance thou art returned so soon?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: Returned so soon! rather approached too late:
The capon burns, the pig falls from the spit,
The clock hath strucken twelve upon the bell;
My mistress made it one upon my cheek:
She is so hot because the meat is cold;
The meat is cold because you come not home;
You come not home because you have no stomach;
You have no stomach having broke your fast;
But we that know what 'tis to fast and pray
Are penitent for your default to-day.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Stop in your wind, sir: tell me this, I pray:
Where have you left the money that I gave you?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: O, â sixpence, that I had o' Wednesday last
To pay the saddler for my mistress' crupper?
The saddler had it, sir; I kept it not.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: I am not in a sportive humour now:
Tell me, and dally not, where is the money?
We being strangers here, how darest thou trust
So great a charge from thine own custody?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: I pray you, jest, sir, as you sit at dinner:
I from my mistress come to you in post;
If I return, I shall be post indeed,
For she will score your fault upon my pate.
Methinks your maw, like mine, should be your clock
And strike you home without a messenger.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Come, Dromio, come, these jests are out of season;
Reserve them till a merrier hour than this.
Where is the gold I gave in charge to thee?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: To me, sir? why, you gave no gold to me.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Come on, sir knave, have done your foolishness
And tell me how thou hast disposed thy charge,

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: My charge was but to fetch you from the mart
Home to your house, the Phoenix, sir, to dinner:
My mistress and her sister stays for you.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Now, as I am a Christian, answer me
In what safe place you have bestowed my money,
Or I shall break that merry sconce of yours
That stands on tricks when I am undisposed:
Where is the thousand marks thou hadst of me?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: I have some marks of yours upon my pate,
Some of my mistress' marks upon my shoulders,
But not a thousand marks between you both.
If I should pay your worship those again,
Perchance you will not bear them patiently.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Thy mistress' marks? what mistress, slave, hast thou?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: Your worship's wife, my mistress at the Phoenix;
She that doth fast till you come home to dinner
And prays that you will hie you home to dinner.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: What, wilt thou flout me thus unto my face,
Being forbid? There, take you that, sir knave.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: What mean you, sir? for God sake, hold your hands!
Nay, an you will not, sir, I'll take my heels. Exit.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Upon my life, by some device or other
The villain is o'erraught of all my money.
They say this town is full of cozenage,
As, nimble jugglers that deceive the eye,
Dark-working sorcerers that change the mind,
Soul-killing witches that deform the body,
Disguised cheaters, prating mountebanks,
And many such-like liberties of sin:
If it prove so, I will be gone the sooner.
I'll to the Centaur, to go seek this slave:
I greatly fear my money is not safe. Exit.

div.head: Act 2, Scene 1
div.stage: The house of ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Neither my husband nor the slave returned,
That in such haste I sent to seek his master!
Sure, Luciana, it is two o'clock.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Perhaps some merchant hath invited him
And from the mart he's somewhere gone to dinner.
Good sister, let us dine and never fret:
A man is master of his liberty:
Time is their master, and, when they see time,
They'll go or come: if so, be patient, sister.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Why should their liberty than ours be more?

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Because their business still lies out o' door.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Look, when I serve him so, he takes it ill.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: O, know he is the bridle of your will.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: There's none but asses will be bridled so.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Why, headstrong liberty is lashed with woe.
There's nothing situate under heaven's eye
But hath his bound, in earth, in sea, in sky:
The beasts, the fishes, and the winged fowls
Are their males' subjects and at their controls:
Man, more divine, the master of all these,
Lord of the wide world and wild watery seas,
Indued with intellectual sense and souls,
Of more pre-eminence than fish and fowls,
Are masters to their females, and their lords:
Then let your will attend on their accords.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: This servitude makes you to keep unwed.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Not this, but troubles of the marriage-bed.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: But, were you wedded, you would bear some sway.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Ere I learn love, I'll practise to obey.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: How if your husband start some other where?

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Till he come home again, I would forbear.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Patience unmoved! no marvel though she pause;
They can be meek that have no other cause.
A wretched soul, bruised with adversity,
We bid be quiet when we hear it cry;
But were we burdened with like weight of pain,
As much or more we should ourselves complain:
So thou, that hast no unkind mate to grieve thee,
With urging helpless patience would relieve me;
But, if thou live to see like right bereft,
This fool-begged patience in thee will be left.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Well, I will marry one day, but to try.
Here comes your man; now is your husband nigh. Enter DROMIO of Ephesus.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Say, is your tardy master now at hand?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.ab: Nay, he's at two hands with me, and that my two ears
can witness.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Say, didst thou speak with him? know'st thou his mind?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: Ay, ay, he told his mind upon mine ear:
Beshrew his hand, I scarce could understand it.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Spake he so doubtfully, thou couldst not feel his meaning?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.ab: Nay, he struck so plainly, I could too well feel
his blows; and withal so doubtfully that I could
scarce understand them.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: But say, I prithee, is he coming home?
It seems he hath great care to please his wife.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: Why, mistress, sure my master is horn-mad.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Horn-mad, thou villain!

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: I mean not cuckold-mad;
But, sure, he is stark mad.
When I desired him to come home to dinner,
He asked me for a thousand marks in gold:
â'Tis dinnertime,â quoth I; âMy gold!â quoth he:
âYour meat doth burn,â quoth I; âMy gold!â quoth he:
âWill you come?â quoth I; âMy gold!â quoth he,
âWhere is the thousand marks I gave thee, villain?â
âThe pig,â quoth I, âis burned;â âMy gold!â quoth he;
âMy mistress, sir,â quoth I; âHang up thy mistress!
I know not thy mistress; out on thy mistress!â

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Quoth who?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: Quoth my master:
âI know,â quoth he, âno house, no wife, no mistress.â
So that my errand, due unto my tongue,
I thank him, I bare home upon my shoulders;
For, in conclusion, he did beat me there.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Go back again, thou slave, and fetch him home.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: Go back again, and be new beaten home?
For God's sake, send some other messenger.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Back, slave, or I will break thy pate across.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: And he will bless that cross with other beating:
Between you I shall have a holy head.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Hence, prating peasant! fetch thy master home.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: Am I so round with you as you with me,
That like a football you do spurn me thus?
You spurn me hence, and he will spurn me hither:
If I last in this service, you must case me in leather. Exit.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Fie, how impatience loureth in your face!

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: His company must do his minions grace,
Whilst I at home starve for a merry look.
Hath homely age the alluring beauty took
From my poor cheek? then he hath wasted it:
Are my discourses dull? barren my wit?
If voluble and sharp discourse be marred,
Unkindness blunts it more than marble hard:
Do their gay vestments his affections bait?
That's not my fault: he's master of my state:
What ruins are in me that can be found,
By him not ruined? then is he the ground
Of my defeatures. My decayed fair
A sunny look of his would soon repair:
But, too unruly deer, he breaks the pale
And feeds from home; poor I am but his stale.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Self-harming jealousy! fie, beat it hence!

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Unfeeling fools can with such wrongs dispense.
I know his eye doth homage otherwhere;
Or else what lets it but he would be here?
Sister, you know he promised me a chain;
Would that alone, a' love he would detain,
So he would keep fair quarter with his bed!
I see the jewel best enamelled
Will lose his beauty; yet the gold bides still,
That others touch, and often touching will
Where gold: and no man that hath a name,
By falsehood and corruption doth it shame.
Since that my beauty cannot please his eye,
I'll weep what's left away, and weeping die.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: How many fond fools serve mad jealousy! Exeunt.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: The gold I gave to Dromio is laid up
Safe at the Centaur; and the heedful slave
Is wandered forth, in care to seek me out
By computation and mine host's report.
I could not speak with Dromio since at first
I sent him from the mart. See, here he comes. Enter DROMIO of Syracuse.
How now, sir! is your merry humour altered?
As you love strokes, so jest with me again.
You know no Centaur? you received no gold?
Your mistress sent to have me home to dinner?
My house was at the Phoenix? Wast thou mad,
That thus so madly thou didst answer me?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: What answer, sir? when spake I such a word?

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Even now, even here, not half an hour since.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: I did not see you since you sent me hence,
Home to the Centaur, with the gold you gave me.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Villain, thou didst deny the gold's receipt,
And told'st me of a mistress and a dinner;
For which, I hope, thou felt'st I was displeased.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: I am glad to see you in this merry vein:
What means this jest? I pray you, master, tell me.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Yea, dost thou jeer and flout me in the teeth?
Think'st thou I jest? Hold, take thou that, and that. Beating him.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: Hold, sir, for God's sake! now your jest is earnest:
Upon what bargain do you give it me?

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Because that I familiarly sometimes
Do use you for my fool and chat with you,
Your sauciness will jest upon my love
And make a common of my serious hours.
When the sun shines let foolish gnats make sport,
But creep in crannies when he hides his beams.
If you will jest with me, know my aspect
And fashion your demeanour to my looks,
Or I will beat this method in your sconce.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Sconce call you it? so you would leave battering,
I had rather have it a head: and you use these
blows long, I must get a sconce for my head and
insconce it too; or else I shall seek my wit in my
shoulders. But, I pray, sir, why am I beaten?

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Dost thou not know?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Nothing, sir, but that I am beaten.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Shall I tell you why?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Ay, sir, and wherefore; for they say every why hath a
wherefore.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Why, first, â for flouting me; and then, wherefore, â
For urging it the second time to me.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: Was there ever any man thus beaten out of season,
When in the why and the wherefore is neither rhyme nor reason?
Well, sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Thank me, sir! for what?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Marry, sir, for this something that you gave me for
nothing.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: I'll make you amends next, to give you nothing for
something. But say, sir, is it dinnertime?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: No, sir; I think the meat wants that I have.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: In good time, sir; what's that?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Basting.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Well, sir, then 'twill be dry.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: If it be, sir, I pray you, eat none of it.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Your reason?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Lest it make you choleric and purchase me another dry
basting.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Well, sir, learn to jest in good time: there's a time
for all things.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: I durst have denied that, before you were so choleric.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: By what rule, sir?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Marry, sir, by a rule as plain as the plain bald pate
of father Time himself.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Let's hear it.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: There's no time for a man to recover his hair that
grows bald by nature.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: May he not do it by fine and recovery?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Yes, to pay a fine for a periwig and recover the lost
hair of another man.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Why is Time such a niggard of hair, being, as it is,
so plentiful an excrement?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Because it is a blessing that he bestows on
beasts; and what he hath scanted men in hair he hath
given them in wit.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Why, but there's many a man hath more hair than wit.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Not a man of those but he hath the wit to lose his
hair.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Why, thou didst conclude hairy men plain dealers
without wit.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: The plainer dealer, the sooner lost: yet he loseth it
in a kind of jollity.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: For what reason?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: For two; and sound ones too.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Nay, not sound, I pray you.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Sure ones, then.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Nay, not sure, in a thing falsing.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Certain ones then.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Name them.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: The one, to save the money that he spends in
tiring; the other that at dinner they should not drop
in his porridge.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: You would all this time have proved there is no time
for all things.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Marry, and did, sir; namely, e'en no time to recover
hair lost by nature.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: But your reason was not substantial, why there is no
time to recover.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Thus I mend it: Time himself is bald and therefore to
the world's end will have bald followers.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: I knew 'twould be a bald conclusion:
But, soft! who wafts us yonder? Enter ADRIANA and LUCIANA.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Ay, ay, Antipholus, look strange and frown:
Some other mistress hath thy sweet aspects;
I am not Adriana nor thy wife.
The time was once when thou unurged wouldst vow
That never words were music to thine ear,
That never object pleasing in thine eye,
That never touch well welcome to thy hand,
That never meat sweet-savoured in thy taste,
Unless I spake, or looked, or touched, or carved to thee.
How comes it now, my husband, O, how comes it,
That thou art then estranged from thyself?
Thyself I call it, being strange to me,
That, undividable, incorporate,
Am better than thy dear self's better part.
Ah, do not tear away thyself from me!
For know, my love, as easy mayest thou fall
A drop of water in the breaking gulf,
And take unmingled thence that drop again,
Without addition or diminishing,
As take from me thyself and not me too.
How dearly would it touch thee to the quick,
Shouldst thou but hear I were licentious
And that this body, consecrate to thee,
By ruffian lust should be contaminate!
Wouldst thou not spit at me and spurn at me
And hurl the name of husband in my face
And tear the stained skin off my harlot brow
And from my false hand cut the wedding-ring
And break it with a deep-divorcing vow?
I know thou canst; and therefore see thou do it.
I am possessed with an adulterate blot;
My blood is mingled with the crime of lust:
For if we two be one and thou play false,
I do digest the poison of thy flesh,
Being strumpeted by thy contagion.
Keep then fair league and truce with thy true bed;
I live dis-stained, thou undishonoured.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Plead you to me, fair dame? I know you not:
In Ephesus I am but two hours old,
As strange unto your town as to your talk;
Who, every word by all my wit being scanned,
Wants wit in all one word to understand.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Fie, brother! how the world is changed with you!
When were you wont to use my sister thus?
She sent for you by Dromio home to dinner.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: By Dromio?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: By me?

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: By thee; and this thou didst return from him,
That he did buffet thee, and, in his blows,
Denied my house for his, me for his wife.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Did you converse, sir, with this gentlewoman?
What is the course and drift of your compact?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: I, sir? I never saw her till this time.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Villain, thou liest; for even her very words
Didst thou deliver to me on the mart.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: I never spake with her in all my life.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: How can she thus then call us by our names?
Unless it be by inspiration.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: How ill agrees it with your gravity
To counterfeit thus grossly with your slave,
Abetting him to thwart me in my mood!
Be it my wrong you are from me exempt,
But wrong not that wrong with a more contempt.
Come, I will fasten on this sleeve of thine:
Thou art an elm, my husband, I a vine,
Whose weakness, married to thy stronger state,
Makes me with thy strength to communicate:
If aught possess thee from me, it is dross,
Usurping ivy, brier, or idle moss;
Who, all for want of pruning, with intrusion
Infect thy sap and live on thy confusion.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: To me she speaks; she moves me for her theme:
What, was I married to her in my dream?
Or sleep I now and think I hear all this?
What error drives our eyes and ears amiss?
Until I know this sure uncertainty,
I'll entertain the offered fallacy.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Dromio, go bid the servants spread for dinner.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: O, for my beads! I cross me for a sinner.
This is the fairy land: O spite of spites!
We talk with goblins, owls and sprites:
If we obey them not, this will ensue,
They'll suck our breath or pinch us black and blue.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Why pratest thou to thyself and answer'st not?
Dromio, thou drumble, thou snail, thou slug, thou sot!

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: I am transformed, master, am not I?

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: I think thou art in mind, and so am I.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: Nay, master, both in mind and in my shape.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Thou hast thine own form.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: No, I am an ape.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: If thou art changed to aught, 'tis to an ass.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: 'Tis true; she rides me and I long for grass.
'Tis so, I am an ass; else it could never be
But I should know her as well as she knows me.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Come, come, no longer will I be a fool,
To put the finger in the eye and weep,
Whilst man and master laughs my woes to scorn.
Come, sir, to dinner. Dromio, keep the gate.
Husband, I'll dine above with you to-day
And shrive you of a thousand idle pranks.
Sirrah, if any ask you for your master,
Say he dines forth, and let no creature enter.
Come, sister. Dromio, play the porter well.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Am I in earth, in heaven, or in hell?
Sleeping or waking? mad or well-advised?
Known unto these, and to myself disguised!
I'll say as they say and persever so,
And in this mist at all adventures go.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: Master, shall I be porter at the gate?

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Ay; and let none enter, lest I break your pate.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Come, come, Antipholus, we dine too late. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 1
div.stage: Before the house of ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus.
Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus, DROMIO of Ephesus, ANGELO, and BALTHAZAR.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Good Signior Angelo, you must excuse us all;
My wife is shrewish when I keep not hours:
Say that I lingered with you at your shop
To see the making of her carcanet,
And that to-morrow you will bring it home.
But here's a villain that would face me down
He met me on the mart and that I beat him,
And charged him with a thousand marks in gold,
And that I did deny my wife and house.
Thou drunkard, thou, what didst thou mean by this?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: Say what you will, sir, but I know what I know;
That you beat me at the mart, I have your hand to show:
If the skin were parchment, and the blows you gave were ink,
Your own handwriting would tell you what I think.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: I think thou art an ass.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: Marry, so it doth appear
By the wrongs I suffer and the blows I bear.
I should kick, being kicked; and, being at that pass,
You would keep from my heels and beware of an ass.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Y' are sad, Signior Balthazar: pray God our cheer
May answer my good will and your good welcome here.

sp.speaker: Balthazar
sp.l: I hold your dainties cheap, sir, and your welcome dear.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: O, Signior Balthazar, either at flesh or fish,
A table full of welcome makes scarce one dainty dish.

sp.speaker: Balthazar
sp.l: Good meat, sir, is common; that every churl affords.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: And welcome more common; for that's nothing but words.

sp.speaker: Balthazar
sp.l: Small cheer and great welcome makes a merry feast.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Ay to a niggardly host and more sparing guest:
But though my cates be mean, take them in good part;
Better cheer may you have, but not with better heart.
But, soft! my door is locked. Go bid them let us in.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: Maud, Bridget, Marian, Cicel, Gillian, Ginn!

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: Mome, malt-horse, capon, coxcomb, idiot, patch!
Either get thee from the door, or sit down at the hatch.
Dost thou conjure for wenches, that thou call'st for such store,
When one is one too many? Go, get thee from the door.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: What patch is made our porter? My master stays in the street.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: Let him walk from whence he came, lest he catch cold on's feet.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Who talks within there? ho, open the door!

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: Right, sir; I'll tell you when, and you'll tell me wherefore.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Wherefore? for my dinner: I have not dined to-day.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: Nor to-day here you must not; come again when you may.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: What art thou that keepest me out from the house I owe?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: The porter for this time, sir, and my name is Dromio.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: O villain! thou hast stolen both mine office and my name.
The one ne'er got me credit, the other mickle blame.
If thou hadst been Dromio to-day in my place,
Thou wouldst have changed thy face for a
name or thy name for an ass.

sp.speaker: Luce
sp.l: What a coil is there, Dromio? who are those at the gate?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: Let my master in, Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce
sp.l: Faith, no; he comes too late;
And so tell your master.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: O Lord, I must laugh!
Have at you with a proverb â Shall I set in my staff?

sp.speaker: Luce
sp.l: Have at you with another; that's â When? can you tell?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: If thy name be called Luce, â Luce, thou hast answered him well.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Do you hear, you minion? you'll let us in, I hope?

sp.speaker: Luce
sp.l: I thought to have asked you.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: And you said no.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: So, come, help: well struck! there was blow for blow.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Thou baggage, let me in.

sp.speaker: Luce
sp.l: Can you tell for whose sake?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: Master, knock the door hard.

sp.speaker: Luce
sp.l: Let him knock till it ache.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: You'll cry for this, minion, if I beat the door down.

sp.speaker: Luce
sp.l: What needs all that, and a pair of stocks in the town?

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Who is that at the door that keeps all this noise?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: By my troth, your town is troubled with unruly boys.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Are you there, wife? you might have come before.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Your wife, sir knave! go get you from the door.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: If you went in pain, master, this âknaveâ would go sore.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Here is neither cheer, sir, nor welcome: we would fain have either.

sp.speaker: Balthazar
sp.l: In debating which was best, we shall part with neither.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: They stand at the door, master; bid them welcome hither.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: There is something in the wind, that we cannot get in.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: You would say so, master, if your garments were thin.
Your cake here is warm within; you stand here in the cold:
It would make a man mad as a buck, to be so bought and sold.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Go fetch me something: I'll break ope the gate.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: Break any breaking here, and I'll break your knave's pate.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: A man may break a word with you, sir, and words are but wind,
Ay, and break it in your face, so he break it not behind.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: It seems thou want'st breaking: out upon thee, hind!

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: Here's too much âout upon thee!â I pray thee, let me in.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: Ay, when fowls have no feathers and fish have no fin.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Well, I'll break in: go borrow me a crow.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: A crow without feather? Master, mean you so?
For a fish without a fin, there's a fowl without a feather:
If a crow help us in, sirrah, we'll pluck a crow together.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Go get thee gone; fetch me an iron crow.

sp.speaker: Balthazar
sp.l: Have patience, sir; O, let it not be so!
Herein you war against your reputation
And draw within the compass of suspect
The unviolated honour of your wife,
Once this, â your long experience of her wisdom,
Her sober virtue, years and modesty,
Plead on her part some cause to you unknown;
And doubt not, sir, but she will well excuse
Why at this time the doors are made against you.
Be ruled by me: depart in patience,
And let us to the Tiger all to dinner,
And about evening come yourself alone
To know the reason of this strange restraint.
If by strong hand you offer to break in
Now in the stirring passage of the day,
A vulgar comment will be made of it,
And that supposed by the common rout
Against your yet ungalled estimation
That may with foul intrusion enter in
And dwell upon your grave when you are dead;
For slander lives upon succession,
For ever housed where it gets possession.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: You have prevailed: I will depart in quiet,
And, in despite of mirth, mean to be merry.
I know a wench of excellent discourse,
Pretty and witty; wild, and yet, too, gentle:
There will we dine. This woman that I mean,
My wife â but, I protest, without desert â
Hath oftentimes upbraided me withal:
To her will we to dinner. To Ang.
Get you home
And fetch the chain; by this I know 'tis made:
Bring it, I pray you, to the Porpentine;
For there's the house: that chain will I bestow â
Be it for nothing but to spite my wife â
Upon mine hostess there: good sir, make haste.
Since mine own doors refuse to entertain me,
I'll knock elsewhere, to see if they'll disdain me.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: I'll meet you at that place some hour hence.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Do so. This jest shall cost me some expense. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 2
div.stage: Enter LUCIANA and ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: And may it be that you have quite forgot
A husband's office? shall, Antipholus.
Even in the spring of love, thy love-springs rot?
Shall love, in building, grow so ruinous?
If you did wed my sister for her wealth,
Then for her wealth's sake use her with more kindness:
Or if you like elsewhere, do it by stealth;
Muffle your false love with some show of blindness:
Let not my sister read it in your eye;
Be not thy tongue thy own shame's orator;
Look sweet, speak fair, become disloyalty;
Apparel vice like virtue's harbinger;
Bear a fair presence, though your heart be tainted;
Teach sin the carriage of a holy saint;
Be secret-false: what need she be acquainted?
What simple thief brags of his own attaint?
'Tis double wrong, to truant with your bed
And let her read it in thy looks at board:
Shame hath a bastard fame, well managed;
Ill deeds is doubled with an evil word.
Alas, poor women! make us but believe,
Being compact of credit, that you love us;
Though others have the arm, show us the sleeve;
We in your motion turn and you may move us.
Then, gentle brother, get you in again;
Comfort my sister, cheer her, call her wife:
'Tis holy sport to be a little vain,
When the sweet breath of flattery conquers strife.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Sweet mistress, â what your name is else, I know not,
Nor by what wonder you do hit of mine, â
Less in your knowledge and your grace you show not
Than our earth's wonder, more than earth divine.
Teach me, dear creature, how to think and speak;
Lay open to my earthy gross conceit,
Smothered in errors, feeble, shallow, weak,
The folded meaning of your words' deceit.
Against my soul's pure truth why labour you
To make it wander in an unknown field?
Are you a god? would you create me new?
Transform me then, and to your power I'll yield.
But if that I am I, then well I know
Your weeping sister is no wife of mine,
Nor to her bed no homage do I owe:
Far more, far more to you do I decline.
O, train me not, sweet mermaid, with thy note,
To drown me in thy sister's flood of tears:
Sing, siren, for thyself and I will dote:
Spread o'er the silver waves thy golden hairs,
And as a bed I'll take them and there lie,
And in that glorious supposition think
He gains by death that hath such means to die:
Let Love, being light, be drowned if she sink!

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: What, are you mad, that you do reason so?

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Not mad, but mated; how, I do not know.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: It is a fault that springeth from your eye.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: For gazing on your beams, fair sun, being by.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Gaze when you should, and that will clear your sight.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: As good to wink, sweet love, as look on night.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Why call you me love? call my sister so.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Thy sister's sister.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: That's my sister.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: No;
It is thyself, mine own self's better part,
Mine eye's clear eye, my dear heart's dearer heart,
My food, my fortune and my sweet hope's aim,
My sole earth's heaven and my heaven's claim.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: All this my sister is, or else should be.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Call thyself sister, sweet, for I am thee.
Thee will I love and with thee lead my life:
Thou hast no husband yet nor I no wife.
Give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: O, soft, sir! hold you still:
I'll fetch my sister, to get her good will. Exit. Enter DROMIO of Syracuse.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Why, how now, Dromio! where runn'st thou so fast?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Do you know me, sir? am I Dromio? am I your man? am I
myself?

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Thou art Dromio, thou art my man, thou art thyself.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: I am an ass, I am a woman's man and besides myself.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: What woman's man? and how besides thyself?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Marry, sir, besides myself, I am due to a woman;
one that claims me, one that haunts me, one that will
have me.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: What claim lays she to thee?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Marry, sir, such claim as you would lay to your
horse; and she would have me as a beast; not
that, I being a beast, she would have me; but
that she, being a very beastly creature, lays claim to
me.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: What is she?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: A very reverent body; ay, such a one as a man
may not speak of without he say âSir-reverence.â
I have but lean luck in the match, and yet is she a
wondrous fat marriage.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: How dost thou mean a fat marriage?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Marry, sir, she's the kitchen wench and all
grease; and I know not what use to put her to
but to make a lamp of her and run from her by
her own light. I warrant, her rags and the tallow
in them will burn a Poland winter: if she lives
till doomsday, she'll burn a week longer than the
whole world.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: What complexion is she of?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Swart, like my shoe, but her face nothing like
so clean kept: for why, she sweats; a man may go over
shoes in the grime of it.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: That's a fault that water will mend.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: No, sir, 'tis in grain; Noah's flood could not do it.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: What's her name?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Nell, sir; but her name and three quarters, that's
an ell and three quarters, will not measure her from
hip to hip.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Then she bears some breadth?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: No longer from head to foot than from hip to hip:
she is spherical, like a globe; I could find out
countries in her.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: In what part of her body stands Ireland?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Marry, sir, in her buttocks: I found it out by the
bogs.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Where Scotland?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: I found it by the barrenness; hard in the palm of the
hand.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Where France?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: In her forehead; armed and reverted, making war
against her heir.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Where England?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: I looked for the chalky cliffs, but I could find
no whiteness in them; but I guess it stood in
her chin, by the salt rheum that ran between France
and it.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Where Spain?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Faith, I saw it not; but I felt it hot in her breath.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Where America, the Indies?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: O, sir, upon her nose, all o'er embellished with
rubies, carbuncles, sapphires, declining their
rich aspect to the hot breath of Spain; who sent whole
armadoes of caracks to be ballast at her nose.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Where stood Belgia, the Netherlands?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: O, sir, I did not look so low. To conclude, this
drudge, or diviner, laid claim to me; called me
Dromio; swore I was assured to her; told me what
privy marks I had about me, as, the mark of my
shoulder, the mole in my neck, the great wart on my
left arm, that I amazed ran from her as a witch:
sp.l: And, I think, if my breast had not been made of faith and my heart of steel,
She had transformed me to a curtal dog and made me turn i' the wheel.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Go hie thee presently, post to the road:
And if the wind blow any way from shore,
I will not harbour in this town to-night:
If any bark put forth, come to the mart,
Where I will walk till thou return to me.
If every one knows us and we know none,
'Tis time, I think, to trudge, pack and be gone.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: As from a bear a man would run for life,
So fly I from her that would be my wife. Exit.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: There's none but witches do inhabit here;
And therefore 'tis high time that I were hence.
She that doth call me husband, even my soul
Doth for a wife abhor. But her fair sister,
Possessed with such a gentle sovereign grace,
Of such enchanting presence and discourse,
Hath almost made me traitor to myself:
But, lest myself be guilty to self-wrong,
I'll stop mine ears against the mermaid's song. Enter ANGELO with the chain.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Master Antipholus, â

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Ay, that's my name.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: I know it well, sir, lo, here's the chain.
I thought to have ta'en you at the Porpentine:
The chain unfinished made me stay thus long.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: What is your will that I shall do with this?

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: What please yourself, sir: I have made it for you.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Made it for me, sir! I bespoke it not.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Not once, nor twice, but twenty times you have.
Go home with it and please your wife withal;
And soon at suppertime I'll visit you
And then receive my money for the chain.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: I pray you, sir, receive the money now,
For fear you ne'er see chain nor money more.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: You are a merry man, sir: fare you well. Exit.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: What I should think of this, I cannot tell:
But this I think, there's no man is so vain
That would refuse so fair an offered chain.
I see a man here needs not live by shifts,
When in the streets he meets such golden gifts.
I'll to the mart and there for Dromio stay:
If any ship put out, then straight away. Exit.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter Second Merchant, ANGELO, and an Officer.

sp.speaker: Second Merchant
sp.l: You know since Pentecost the sum is due,
And since I have not much importuned you;
Nor now I had not, but that I am bound
To Persia, and want guilders for my voyage:
Therefore make present satisfaction,
Or I'll attach you by this officer.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Even just the sum that I do owe to you
Is growing to me by Antipholus,
And in the instant that I met with you
He had of me a chain: at five o'clock
I shall receive the money for the same.
Pleaseth you walk with me down to his house,
I will discharge my bond and thank you too. Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus from the courtezan's.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: That labour may you save; see where he comes.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: While I go to the goldsmith's house, go thou
And buy a rope's end: that will I bestow
Among my wife and her confederates,
For locking me out of my doors by day.
But, soft! I see the goldsmith. Get thee gone;
Buy thou a rope and bring it home to me.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: I buy a thousand pound a year: I buy a rope. Exit.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: A man is well holp up that trusts to you:
I promised your presence and the chain;
But neither chain nor goldsmith came to me.
Belike you thought our love would last too long,
If it were chained together, and therefore came not.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Saving your merry humour, here's the note
How much your chain weighs to the utmost carat,
The fineness of the gold and chargeful fashion,
Which doth amount to three odd ducats more
Than I stand debted to this gentleman:
I pray you, see him presently discharged,
For he is bound to sea and stays but for it.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: I am not furnished with the present money;
Besides, I have some business in the town.
Good signior, take the stranger to my house
And with you take the chain and bid my wife
Disburse the sum on the receipt thereof:
Perchance I will be there as soon as you.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Then you will bring the chain to her yourself?

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: No; bear it with you, lest I come not time enough.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Well, sir, I will. Have you the chain about you?

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: An if I have not, sir, I hope you have;
Or else you may return without your money.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Nay, come, I pray you, sir, give me the chain:
Both wind and tide stays for this gentleman,
And I, to blame, have held him here too long.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Good Lord! you use this dalliance to excuse
Your breach of promise to the Porpentine.
I should have chid you for not bringing it,
But, like a shrew, you first begin to brawl.

sp.speaker: Second Merchant
sp.l: The hour steals on; I pray you, sir, dispatch.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: You hear how he importunes me; â the chain!

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Why, give it to my wife and fetch your money.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Come, come, you know I gave it you even now.
Either send the chain or send me by some token.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Fie, now you run this humour out of breath,
Come, where's the chain? I pray you, let me see it.

sp.speaker: Second Merchant
sp.l: My business cannot brook this dalliance.
Good sir, say whether you'll answer me or no:
If not, I'll leave him to the officer.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: I answer you! what should I answer you?

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: The money that you owe me for the chain.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: I owe you none till I receive the chain.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: You know I gave it you half an hour since.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: You gave me none: you wrong me much to say so.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: You wrong me more, sir, in denying it;
Consider how it stands upon my credit.

sp.speaker: Second Merchant
sp.l: Well, officer, arrest him at my suit.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: I do; and charge you in the duke's name to obey me.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: This touches me in reputation.
Either consent to pay this sum for me
Or I attach you by this officer.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Consent to pay thee that I never had!
Arrest me, foolish fellow, if thou darest.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Here is thy fee; arrest him, officer,
I would not spare my brother in this case,
If he should scorn me so apparently.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: I do arrest you, sir: you hear the suit.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: I do obey thee till I give thee bail.
But, sirrah, you shall buy this sport as dear
As all the metal in your shop will answer.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Sir, sir, I shall have law in Ephesus,
To your notorious shame; I doubt it not. Enter DROMIO of Syracuse, from the bay.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: Master, there's a bark of Epidamnum
That stays but till her owner comes aboard,
And then, sir, she bears away. Our fraughtage, sir,
I have conveyed aboard; and I have bought
The oil, the balsamum and aqua-vitae.
The ship is in her trim: the merry wind
Blows fair from land: they stay for nought at all
But for their owner, master, and yourself.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: How now! a madman! Why, thou peevish sheep,
What ship of Epidamnum stays for me?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: A ship you sent me to, to hire waftage.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Thou drunken slave, I sent thee for a rope;
And told thee to what purpose and what end.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: You sent me for a rope's end as soon:
You sent me to the bay, sir, for a bark.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: I will debate this matter at more leisure
And teach your ears to list me with more heed.
To Adriana, villain, hie thee straight:
Give her this key, and tell her, in the desk
That's covered o'er with Turkish tapestry,
There is a purse of ducats; let her send it:
Tell her I am arrested in the street
And that shall bail me; hie thee, slave, be gone!
On, officer, to prison till it come. Exeunt Sec. Merchant, Angelo, Officer, and Ant. E.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: To Adriana! that is where we dined,
Where Dowsabel did claim me for her husband:
She is too big, I hope, for me to compass.
Thither I must, although against my will,
For servants must their masters' minds fulfil. Exit.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 2
div.stage: The house of ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Ah, Luciana, did he tempt thee so?
Mightst thou perceive austerely in his eye
That he did plead in earnest? yea or no?
Looked he or red or pale, or sad or merrily?
What observation madest thou in this case
Of his heart's meteors tilting in his face?

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: First he denied you had in him no right.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: He meant he did me none; the more my spite.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Then swore he that he was a stranger here.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: And true he swore, though yet forsworn he were.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Then pleaded I for you.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: And what said he?

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: That love I begged for you he begged of me.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: With what persuasion did he tempt thy love?

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: With words that in an honest suit might move.
First he did praise my beauty, then my speech.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Didst speak him fair?

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Have patience, I beseech.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: I cannot, nor I will not, hold me still;
My tongue, though not my heart, shall have his will.
He is deformed, crooked, old and sere,
Ill-faced, worse bodied, shapeless every where;
Vicious, ungentle, foolish, blunt, unkind,
Stigmatical in making, worse in mind.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Who would be jealous then of such a one?
No evil lost is wailed when it is gone.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Ah, but I think him better than I say,
And yet would herein others' eyes were worse.
Far from her nest the lapwing cries away:
My heart prays for him, though my tongue do curse. Enter DROMIO of Syracuse.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: Here! go; the desk, the purse! sweat now, make haste.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: How hast thou lost thy breath?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: By running fast.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Where is thy master, Dromio? is he well?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: No, he's in Tartar limbo, worse than hell.
A devil in an everlasting garment hath him:
One whose hard heart is buttoned up with steel;
A fiend, a fairy, pitiless and rough;
A wolf, nay, worse, a fellow all in buff;
A back-friend, a shoulder-clapper, one that countermands
The passages of alleys, creeks and narrow lands;
A hound that runs counter and yet draws dry-foot well;
One that before the judgement carries poor souls to hell.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Why, man, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: I do not know the matter: he is 'rested on the case.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: What, is he arrested? Tell me at whose suit.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: I know not at whose suit he is arrested well;
But 'a's in a suit of buff which 'rested him, that can I tell.
Will you send him, mistress, redemption, the money in his desk?

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Go fetch it, sister. Exit Luciana.
This I wonder at,
That he, unknown to me, should be in debt,
Tell me, was he arrested on a band?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: Not on a band, but on a stronger thing;
A chain, a chain! Do you not hear it ring?

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: What, the chain?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: No, no, the bell: 'tis time that I were gone:
It was two ere I left him, and now the clock strikes one,

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: The hours come back! that did I never hear.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: O, yes; if any hour meet a sergeant, 'a turns back for very fear.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: As if Time were in debt! how fondly dost thou reason!

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: Time is a very bankrupt, and owes more than he's worth, to season.
Nay, he's a thief too: have you not heard men say,
That Time comes stealing on by night and day?
If 'a be in debt and theft, and a sergeant in the way,
Hath he not reason to turn back an hour in a day? Re-enter LUCIANA with a purse.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Go, Dromio; there's the money, bear it straight,
And bring thy master home immediately.
Come, sister: I am pressed down with conceit â
Conceit, my comfort and my injury. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: There's not a man I meet but doth salute me
As if I were their well-acquainted friend;
And every one doth call me by my name.
Some tender money to me; some invite me;
Some other give me thanks for kindnesses;
Some offer me commodities to buy:
Even now a tailor called me in his shop
And showed me silks that he had bought for me
And therewithal took measure of my body.
Sure, these are but imaginary wiles
And Lapland sorcerers inhabit here. Enter DROMIO of Syracuse.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Master, here's the gold you sent me for. What,
have you got the picture of old Adam new apparelled?

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: What gold is this? what Adam dost thou mean?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Not that Adam that kept the Paradise, but that
Adam that keeps the prison: he that goes in the
calf's-skin that was killed for the Prodigal; he
that came behind you, sir, like an evil angel, and bid
you forsake your liberty.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: I understand thee not.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: No? why, 'tis a plain case: he that went, like
a bass-viol, in a case of leather; the man, sir,
that, when gentlemen are tired, gives them a sob
and 'rests them: he, sir, that takes pity on
decayed men and gives them suits of durance; he
that sets up his rest to do more exploits with his
mace than a morris-pike.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: What, thou meanest an officer?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Ay, sir, the sergeant of the band; he that brings
any man to answer it that breaks his band; one
that thinks a man always going to bed, and says, âGod
give you good rest!â

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Well, sir, there rest in your foolery. Is there any
ships puts forth to-night? may we be gone?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Why, sir, I brought you word an hour since that
the bark Expedition put forth to-night; and then
were you hindered by the sergeant, to tarry for
the hoy Delay. Here are the angels that you sent for
to deliver you.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: The fellow is distract, and so am I;
And here we wander in illusions:
Some blessed power deliver us from hence! Enter a Courtezan.

sp.speaker: Courtezan
sp.l: Well met, well met, Master Antipholus.
I see, sir, you have found the goldsmith now:
Is that the chain you promised me to-day?

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Satan, avoid! I charge thee, tempt me not.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Master, is this Mistress Satan?

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: It is the devil.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Nay, she is worse, she is the devil's dam; and
here she comes in the habit of a light wench:
and thereof comes that the wenches say âGod damn
me;â that's as much to say âGod make me a light
wench.â It is written, they appear to men like
angels of light: light is an effect of fire, and
fire will burn; ergo, light wenches will burn. Come
not near her.

sp.speaker: Courtezan
sp.l: Your man and you are marvellous merry, sir.
Will you go with me? We'll mend our dinner here?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Master, if you do, expect spoon-meat; or bespeak a
long spoon.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.ab: Why, Dromio?

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Marry, he must have a long spoon that must eat with
the devil.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Avoid then, fiend! what tell'st thou me of supping?
Thou art, as you are all, a sorceress:
I conjure thee to leave me and be gone.

sp.speaker: Courtezan
sp.l: Give me the ring of mine you had at dinner,
Or, for my diamond, the chain you promised,
And I'll be gone, sir, and not trouble you.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: Some devils ask but the parings of one's nail,
A rush, a hair, a drop of blood, a pin,
A nut, a cherry-stone;
But she, more covetous, would have a chain.
Master, be wise: and if you give it her,
The devil will shake her chain and fright us with it.

sp.speaker: Courtezan
sp.l: I pray you, sir, my ring, or else the chain:
I hope you do not mean to cheat me so.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Avaunt, thou witch! Come, Dromio, let us go.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: âFly pride,â says the peacock: mistress, that you know. Exeunt Ant. S. and Dro. S.

sp.speaker: Courtezan
sp.l: Now, out of doubt Antipholus is mad,
Else would he never so demean himself.
A ring he hath of mine worth forty ducats,
And for the same he promised me a chain:
Both one and other he denies me now.
The reason that I gather he is mad,
Besides this present instance of his rage,
Is a mad tale he told to-day at dinner,
Of his own doors being shut against his entrance.
Belike his wife, acquainted with his fits,
On purpose shut the doors against his way.
My way is now to hie home to his house,
And tell his wife that, being lunatic,
He rushed into my house and took perforce
My ring away. This course I fittest choose;
For forty ducats is too much to lose. Exit.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 4
div.stage: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and the Officer.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Fear me not, man; I will not break away:
I'll give thee, ere I leave thee, so much money,
To warrant thee, as I am 'rested for.
My wife is in a wayward mood to-day,
And will not lightly trust the messenger.
That I should be attached in Ephesus,
I tell you, 'twill sound harshly in her ears. Enter DROMIO of Ephesus with a rope's-end.
Here comes my man; I think he brings the money.
How now, sir! have you that I sent you for?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: Here's that, I warrant you, will pay them all.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: But where's the money?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: Why, sir, I gave the money for the rope.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Five hundred ducats, villain, for a rope?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: I'll serve you, sir, five hundred at the rate.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: To what end did I bid thee hie thee home?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: To a rope's end, sir; and to that end am I returned.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: And to that end, sir, I will welcome you. Beating him.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.ab: Good sir, be patient.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.ab: Nay, 'tis for me to be patient; I am in adversity.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.ab: Good now, hold thy tongue.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.ab: Nay, rather persuade him to hold his hands.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.ab: Thou whoreson, senseless villain!

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.ab: I would I were senseless, sir, that I might not feel
your blows.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.ab: Thou art sensible in nothing but blows, and so is an
ass.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.ab: I am an ass, indeed; you may prove it by my long
ears. I have served him from the hour of my
nativity to this instant, and have nothing at
his hands for my service but blows. When I am
cold, he heats me with beating; when I am warm,
he cools me with beating: I am waked with it when
I sleep; raised with it when I sit; driven out
of doors with it when I go from home; welcomed
home with it when I return: nay, I bear it on my
shoulders, as a beggar wont her brat; and, I
think, when he hath lamed me, I shall beg with it from
door to door.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Come, go along; my wife is coming yonder. Enter ADRIANA, LUCIANA, the Courtezan, and PINCH.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.ab: Mistress, ârespice finem,â respect your end; or
rather, the prophecy like the parrot, âbeware the
rope's end.â

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.ab: Wilt thou still talk?

sp.speaker: Courtezan
sp.l: How say you now? is not your husband mad?

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: His incivility confirms no less.
Good Doctor Pinch, you are a conjurer;
Establish him in his true sense again,
And I will please you what you will demand.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Alas, how fiery and how sharp he looks!

sp.speaker: Courtezan
sp.l: Mark how he trembles in his ecstasy!

sp.speaker: Pinch
sp.l: Give me your hand and let me feel your pulse.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: There is my hand, and let it feel your ear. Striking him.

sp.speaker: Pinch
sp.l: I charge thee, Satan, housed within this man,
To yield possession to my holy prayers
And to thy state of darkness hie thee straight:
I conjure thee by all the saints in heaven!

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Peace, doting wizard, peace! I am not mad.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: O, that thou wert not, poor distressed soul!

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: You minion, you, are these your customers?
Did this companion with the saffron face
Revel and feast it at my house to-day,
Whilst upon me the guilty doors were shut
And I denied to enter in my house?

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: O husband, God doth know you dined at home;
Where would you had remained until this time,
Free from these slanders and this open shame!

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Dined at home! Thou villain, what sayest thou?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: Sir, sooth to say, you did not dine at home.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Were not my doors locked up and I shut out?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: Perdie, your doors were locked and you shut out.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: And did not she herself revile me there?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: Sans fable, she herself reviled you there.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Did not her kitchen maid rail, taunt, and scorn me?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: Certes, she did; the kitchen vestal scorned you.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: And did not I in rage depart from thence?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: In verity you did; my bones bears witness,
That since have felt the vigour of his rage.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Is't good to soothe him in these contraries?

sp.speaker: Pinch
sp.l: It is no shame: the fellow finds his vein,
And yielding to him humours well his frenzy.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Thou hast suborned the goldsmith to arrest me.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Alas, I sent you money to redeem you,
By Dromio here, who came in haste for it.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: Money by me! heart and good will you might;
But surely, master, not a rag of money.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Went'st not thou to her for a purse of ducats?

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: He came to me and I delivered it.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: And I am witness with her that she did.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: God and the rope-maker bear me witness
That I was sent for nothing but a rope!

sp.speaker: Pinch
sp.l: Mistress, both man and master is possessed;
I know it by their pale and deadly looks:
They must be bound and laid in some dark room.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Say, wherefore didst thou lock me forth to-day?
And why dost thou deny the bag of gold?

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: I did not, gentle husband, lock thee forth.

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: And, gentle master, I received no gold;
But I confess, sir, that we were locked out.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Dissembling villain, thou speak'st false in both.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Dissembling harlot, thou art false in all;
And art confederate with a damned pack
To make a loathsome abject scorn of me:
But with these nails I'll pluck out these false eyes
That would behold in me this shameful sport. Enter three or four, and offer to bind him. He strives.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: O, bind him, bind him! let him not come near me.

sp.speaker: Pinch
sp.l: More company! The fiend is strong within him.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Ay me, poor man, how pale and wan he looks!

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: What, will you murder me? Thou gaoler, thou,
I am thy prisoner: wilt thou suffer them
To make a rescue?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Masters, let him go:
He is my prisoner, and you shall not have him.

sp.speaker: Pinch
sp.l: Go bind this man, for he is frantic too. They offer to bind Dro. E.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: What wilt thou do, thou peevish officer?
Hast thou delight to see a wretched man
Do outrage and displeasure to himself?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: He is my prisoner: if I let him go,
The debt he owes will be required of me.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: I will discharge thee ere I go from thee:
Bear me forthwith unto his creditor,
And, knowing how the debt grows, I will pay it.
Good master doctor, see him safe conveyed
Home to my house. O most unhappy day!

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: O most unhappy strumpet!

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.l: Master, I am here entered in bond for you.

sp.speaker: E. Antipholus
sp.l: Out on thee, villain! wherefore dost thou mad me?

sp.speaker: E. Dromio
sp.ab: Will you be bound for nothing? be mad, good master:
cry âThe devil!â

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: God help, poor souls, how idly do they talk!

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Go bear him hence. Sister, go you with me. Exeunt all but Adriana, Luciana, Officer and Courtezan.
Say now, whose suit is he arrested at?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: One Angelo, a goldsmith: do you know him?

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: I know the man. What is the sum he owes?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Two hundred ducats.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Say, how grows it due?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Due for a chain your husband had of him.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: He did bespeak a chain for me, but had it not.

sp.speaker: Courtezan
sp.l: When as your husband all in rage to-day
Came to my house and took away my ring â
The ring I saw upon his finger now â
Straight after did I meet him with a chain.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: It may be so, but I did never see it.
Come, gaoler, bring me where the goldsmith is:
I long to know the truth hereof at large. Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse with his rapier drawn, and DROMIO of Syracuse.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: God, for thy mercy! they are loose again.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: And come with naked swords. Let's call more help
To have them bound again.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Away! they'll kill us. Exeunt all but Ant. S. and Dro. S.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: I see these witches are afraid of swords.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: She that would be your wife now ran from you.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Come to the Centaur; fetch our stuff from thence:
I long that we were safe and sound aboard.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.ab: Faith, stay here this night; they will surely do
us no harm: you saw they speak us fair, give us
gold: methinks they are such a gentle nation
that, but for the mountain of mad flesh that
claims marriage of me, I could find in my heart to
stay here still and turn witch.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: I will not stay to-night for all the town;
Therefore away, to get our stuff aboard. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: I am sorry, sir, that I have hindered you;
But, I protest, he had the chain of me,
Though most dishonestly he doth deny it.

sp.speaker: Second Merchant
sp.l: How is the man esteemed here in the city?

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Of very reverend reputation, sir,
Of credit infinite, highly beloved,
Second to none that lives here in the city:
His word might bear my wealth at any time.

sp.speaker: Second Merchant
sp.l: Speak softly; yonder, as I think, he walks. Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse and DROMIO of Syracuse.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: 'Tis so; and that self chain about his neck
Which he forswore most monstrously to have.
Good sir, draw near to me, I'll speak to him.
Signior Antipholus, I wonder much
That you would put me to this shame and trouble;
And, not without some scandal to yourself,
With circumstance and oaths so to deny
This chain which now you wear so openly:
Beside the charge, the shame, imprisonment,
You have done wrong to this my honest friend,
Who, but for staying on our controversy,
Had hoisted sail and put to sea to-day:
This chain you had of me; can you deny it?

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: I think I had; I never did deny it.

sp.speaker: Second Merchant
sp.l: Yes, that you did, sir, and forswore it too.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Who heard me to deny it or forswear it?

sp.speaker: Second Merchant
sp.l: These ears of mine, thou know'st, did hear thee.
Fie on thee, wretch! 'tis pity that thou livest
To walk where any honest men resort.

sp.speaker: S. Antipholus
sp.l: Thou art a villain to impeach me thus:
I'll prove mine honour and mine honesty
Against thee presently, if thou darest stand.

sp.speaker: Second Merchant
sp.l: I dare, and do defy thee for a villain. They draw. Enter ADRIANA, LUCIANA, the Courtezan, and others.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Hold, hurt him not, for God sake! he is mad.
Some get within him, take his sword away:
Bind Dromio too, and bear them to my house.

sp.speaker: S. Dromio
sp.l: Run, master, run; for God's sake, take a house!
This is some priory. In, or we are spoiled! Exeunt Ant. S. and Dro. S. to the Priory. Enter the Lady Abbess.

sp.speaker: Aemilia
sp.l: Be quiet, people. Wherefore throng you hither?

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: To fetch my poor distracted husband hence.
Let us come in, that we may bind him fast
And bear him home for his recovery.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: I knew he was not in his perfect wits,

sp.speaker: Second Merchant
sp.l: I am sorry now that I did draw on him.

sp.speaker: Aemilia
sp.l: How long hath this possession held the man?

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: This week he hath been heavy, sour, sad,
And much different from the man he was;
But till this afternoon his passion
Ne'er brake into extremity of rage.

sp.speaker: Aemilia
sp.l: Hath he not lost much wealth by wrack of sea?
Buried some dear friend? Hath not else his eye
Strayed his affection in unlawful love?
A sin prevailing much in youthful men,
Who give their eyes the liberty of gazing.
Which of these sorrows is he subject to?

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: To none of these, except it be the last;
Namely, some love that drew him oft from home.

sp.speaker: Aemilia
sp.l: You should for that have reprehended him.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Why, so I did.

sp.speaker: Aemilia
sp.l: Ay, but not rough enough.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: As roughly as my modesty would let me.

sp.speaker: Aemilia
sp.l: Haply, in private.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: And in assemblies too.

sp.speaker: Aemilia
sp.l: Ay, but not enough.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: It was the copy of our conference:
In bed he slept not for my urging it;
At board he fed not for my urging it;
Alone, it was the subject of my theme;
In company I often glanced it;
Still did I tell him it was vile and bad.

sp.speaker: Aemilia
sp.l: And thereof came it that the man was mad:
The venom clamours of a jealous woman
Poisons more deadly than a mad dog's tooth.
It seems his sleeps were hindered by thy railing,
And thereof comes it that his head is light.
Thou say'st his meat was sauced with thy upbraidings:
Unquiet meals make ill digestions;
Thereof the raging fire of fever bred;
And what's a fever but a fit of madness?
Thou say'st his sports were hindered by thy brawls:
Sweet recreation barred, what doth ensue
But moody and dull melancholy,
Kinsman to grim and comfortless despair,
And at her heels a huge infectious troop
Of pale distemperatures and foes to life?
In food, in sport and life-preserving rest
To be disturbed, would mad or man or beast:
The consequence is then thy jealous fits
Hath scared thy husband from the use of wits.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: She never reprehended him but mildly.
When he demeaned himself rough, rude and wildly.
Why bear you these rebukes and answer not?

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: She did betray me to my own reproof.
Good people, enter and lay hold on him.

sp.speaker: Aemilia
sp.l: No, not a creature enters in my house.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Then let your servants bring my husband forth.

sp.speaker: Aemilia
sp.l: Neither: he took this place for sanctuary,
And it shall privilege him from your hands
Till I have brought him to his wits again,
Or lose my labour in assaying it.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: I will attend my husband, be his nurse,
Diet his sickness, for it is my office,
And will have no attorney but myself;
And therefore let me have him home with me.

sp.speaker: Aemilia
sp.l: Be patient; for I will not let him stir
Till I have used the approved means I have,
With wholesome syrups, drugs and holy prayers,
To make of him a formal man again:
It is a branch and parcel of mine oath,
A charitable duty of my order.
Therefore depart and leave him here with me,

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: I will not hence and leave my husband here:
And ill it doth beseem your holiness
To separate the husband and the wife.

sp.speaker: Aemilia
sp.l: Be quiet and depart: thou shalt not have him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Complain unto the duke of this indignity.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Come, go: I will fall prostrate at his feet
And never rise until my tears and prayers
Have won his grace to come in person hither
And take perforce my husband from the abbess.

sp.speaker: Second Merchant
sp.l: By this, I think, the dial points at five:
Anon, I'm sure, the duke himself in person
Comes this way to the melancholy vale,
The place of death and sorry execution,
Behind the ditches of the abbey here.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Upon what cause?

sp.speaker: Second Merchant
sp.l: To see a reverend Syracusian merchant,
Who put unluckily into this bay
Against the laws and statutes of this town,
Beheaded publicly for his offence.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: See where they come: we will behold his death.

sp.speaker: Luciana
sp.l: Kneel to the duke before he pass the abbey. Enter DUKE, attended; AEGEON bareheaded; with the Headsman and other Officers.

sp.speaker: Solinus
sp.l: Yet once again proclaim it publicly,
If any friend will pay the sum for him,
He shall not die; so much we tender him.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: Justice, most sacred duke, against the abbess!

sp.speaker: Solinus
sp.l: She is a virtuous and a reverend lady:
It cannot be that she hath done thee wrong.

sp.speaker: Adriana
sp.l: May it please your grace, Antipholus, my husband,
Who I made lord of me and all I had,
At your important letters, â this ill day
A most outrageous fit of madness took him;
That desperately he hurried through the street,
With him his bondman, all as mad as he, â
Doing displeasure to the citizens
By rushing in their houses, bearing thence
